metadata.sermon_title: Sermon 163: The New Temple, The New Life
metadata.sermon_start_end: Brothers, if we consider what we were before the coming of grace and what grace has since wrought in us [...] In your distress call out, 'Who will deliver me from this body of death?' And if it's faith and humility which inspire your prayer, Truth itself will reply: 'The grace of God, through Jesus Christ our Lord.'
metadata.liturgical_context: Likely a dedication of a church or an anniversary of a dedication (Encaenia)
metadata.historical_context: Late Antiquity (approx. early 5th century). North Africa. Context of the Pelagian controversy regarding grace and human will.
metadata.notes: Classic patristic homily utilizing allegorical and tropological interpretation.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon excels in the architectural metaphor of the 'Temple,' which serves as the primary lens for the entire discourse. Augustine effectively utilizes the imagery of construction—demolishing, carting away, and dedicating—to describe the internal moral life. The imagery of the 'doctor' and the 'sharp blade' in §8 provides a visceral, sensory experience of God's providence in suffering. However, much of the imagery remains tied to biblical metaphors (the serpent, the apple, the sting of death) rather than fresh, contemporary observations. While the 'ocean of faithlessness' is a strong image, the sermon occasionally leans back into abstract theological categories of 'flesh' and 'spirit' without always grounding them in the concrete sensory details advocated by Paul Scott Wilson.
quotes: On the one hand, we demolish and cart away; and on the other, we make improvements.
What a counter-poison, distilled (so to speak) from the serpent himself.
Even though you beg him to stop when you feel the sharp blade, it’s his very love for you that makes him continue.
strengths: The central metaphor of the human person as a building site is consistently maintained.
The use of medical imagery (tumor, physician, venom) makes the concept of grace tangible.
Vivid personification of the 'old man' Simeon waiting for the 'divine child'.
improvement_points: Incorporate more concrete examples of 'works of the flesh' beyond the biblical list to increase 'showing'.
Develop the 'ocean of faithlessness' image further to provide a more immersive setting.
Use more sensory language regarding the 'stench' of the old life versus the 'fragrance' of the new.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: The sermon balances 'telling' (theological exposition of Romans) with 'showing' through the architectural and medical metaphors, though the former dominates.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: Augustine exhibits extreme stewardship of language, particularly in his nuanced distinctions between 'wanting' and 'doing,' and 'combatants' versus 'conquerors.' Every word is calculated to navigate the fine line between the necessity of human effort and the absolute priority of grace. He avoids vague pieties by defining his terms through the lens of Scripture. The precision in §10 regarding the Law as the 'power of sin' demonstrates a high level of intellectual and linguistic care. There is a clear 'Canaanite' vocabulary (grace, concupiscence, Spirit), but it is used with such technical precision that it functions as a sharp tool rather than a dull cliché. The language is 'loving' in the sense of McEntyre, as it seeks to accurately diagnose the human condition.
quotes: What a venomous wound if venom alone could heal it!
That’s the song of conquerors, not of combatants, for combatants sigh.
Promising means binding yourself to act, not merely stating what you’ll do.
strengths: Exceptional precision in distinguishing between the will and the ability to perform.
Careful handling of the paradox of the Law being 'holy' yet 'killing'.
Avoidance of sloppy generalizations about the Christian life.
improvement_points: The term 'concupiscence' is used frequently and could benefit from more varied synonyms for modern clarity.
Some sentence structures are highly dialectical and may require slower delivery to ensure clarity.
The transition between the 'temple' metaphor and the 'combat' metaphor could be more precisely bridged.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Religious jargon is present but functions as a precise theological grammar that is explained through the text.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon is a masterclass in oral rhetoric. It utilizes frequent staccato questions and answers ('Who is he?' 'The salvation of God.') that create a rhythmic, dialogical flow. The use of parallelism and antithesis ('Down with the old; long live the new!') provides a cadence that is easy to follow and memorable. The rhythm shifts effectively from the slow, contemplative descriptions of Simeon to the rapid-fire battle imagery of the spirit versus the flesh. It is clearly 'oral language,' designed for the ear, utilizing the rhetorical figures of the classical tradition to drive home the 'musicality' of the Gospel message. The repetition of 'Sing to the Lord' acts as a rhythmic refrain that anchors the structure.
quotes: Sing as you build. Sing, and sing well.
The fulness of age was dragging him away, but heartfelt piety was holding him back.
You’re being fought; so fight back, and one of these days you’ll be the victor.
strengths: Effective use of the 'diatribe' style (imaginary dialogue) to maintain engagement.
Strong rhythmic parallels: 'day begotten by day, day come forth from day'.
Excellent variation in sentence length to emphasize key points.
improvement_points: The middle sections on Romans 7 become slightly dense and could use more rhythmic 'breathing room'.
The transition to the 'sting of death' section is somewhat abrupt in its rhythmic shift.
Could utilize more alliteration to enhance the 'song' theme of the sermon.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: This is quintessentially oral language, characterized by direct address and rhetorical questions.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The language of the sermon is rhetorically sophisticated yet accessible, characterized by a dominant architectural metaphor that provides a cohesive visual frame. Augustine’s 'stewardship of language' is evident in his precise theological distinctions, particularly concerning the struggle of the will. The musicality is high, driven by a dialogical rhythm that keeps the listener engaged through questions and rhythmic refrains. While it relies heavily on biblical imagery, it avoids 'kitsch' by maintaining a sharp, almost clinical precision in its diagnosis of the human condition and the operation of grace.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear dramaturgical progression from the 'construction' of the temple to its 'dedication.' It begins with an 'upsetting of equilibrium' by reminding the hearers of what they were before grace. The 'plot' is the tension between the 'already' of Christ’s resurrection and the 'not yet' of the believer's struggle. There is a palpable movement from the external building to the internal heart, and finally to the eschatological victory. However, the structure is somewhat cyclical; it returns to the struggle of the flesh multiple times, which, while theologically consistent, can feel like a 'standstill' rather than a linear journey. The 'turning point' is the intervention of grace in §11, which resolves the tension created by the 'killing letter' of the law.
quotes: Wasn’t that erecting the temple but not yet dedicating it?
But, soldier, why hurry so? Later, later!
Then will be fulfilled …—not 'is,' but 'will be.'
strengths: Strong opening that immediately establishes the 'stakes' of the sermon.
The tension between 'combatant' and 'conqueror' creates a compelling narrative arc.
The conclusion effectively returns to the cry for help, closing the loop of the 'temple' construction.
improvement_points: The transition between §5 and §6 feels like a restart rather than a continuation of the arc.
The middle section on the Law could be more tightly integrated into the 'temple' narrative.
The 'plot' could be strengthened by a more singular, climactic turning point.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey that moves from the present struggle (construction) to the future hope (dedication).

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: Augustine brilliantly 'reframes' the contemporary experience of moral failure through the lens of the Psalms and Paul’s letters. He respects the 'strangeness' of the biblical text (the Law as the power of sin) while making it immediately relevant to the hearer's internal 'war.' The integration of the physical building (the context of the gathering) with the spiritual 'temple' is a classic example of Cilliers' reframing. He does not smooth over the difficulties of the text but uses them to challenge the hearer’s self-reliance. The sermon offers a new frame: the hearer is not a failure, but a 'work in progress'—a temple under construction. This synthesis of 'then' and 'now' is organic and profound.
quotes: Just as we humans improve, there are also buildings which become instruments of grace.
Don’t go imagining that this temple is sited somewhere apart... Sing to the Lord, all the earth!
The Savior gave himself to this old man immediately upon visiting this aging earth.
strengths: Seamless transition between the physical space and the spiritual reality.
Uses the text to challenge the 'context' of human pride and self-sufficiency.
The 'reframing' of suffering as the 'doctor's blade' is a powerful synthesis.
improvement_points: Could include more specific 'contextual' details of the North African setting to ground the 'reframing'.
The connection to the 'heretics and schismatics' is mentioned but not fully integrated into the aesthetic arc.
The 'old man/old earth' parallel could be expanded to include the 'newness' of the current congregation.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: The sermon offers a radical reframing of moral struggle as a sign of God's 'delaying' help for the sake of humility.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: While the sermon is dogmatically firm, it remains an 'open work' in its acknowledgement of the 'not yet.' Augustine does not offer a 'happy ending' in the present life; he leaves the hearer in the 'between' space of combat. By ending with the cry 'Who will deliver me?', he invites the hearer into a continuing relationship of dependence on grace. However, the interpretation of the 'works of the flesh' and the 'Law' is quite monovalent—there is little room for alternative interpretations of the Pauline text. The sermon is 'closed' in its dogmatic certainty but 'open' in its pastoral application, acknowledging the ambivalence of the Christian who 'does not do what they want.'
quotes: But his dream doesn’t come true in this life.
You never reach the point where you no longer have evil inclinations.
How long must this go on? The Lord replies: 'Until you’re thoroughly convinced...'
strengths: Acknowledges the 'ambivalence of existence' by refusing a cheap resolution to the struggle with sin.
Ends with an invitation to prayer rather than a moralistic checklist.
The 'openness' of the 'not yet' dedication respects the reality of the hearer's life.
improvement_points: The rhetorical 'questions' are often 'closed' (the preacher provides the only answer immediately).
Could allow for more mystery regarding *how* grace works, rather than explaining it so systematically.
The distinction between 'us' and 'heretics' closes the space for broader ecclesial reflection.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: A 'semi-open' work: dogmatically closed but pastorally open to the messiness of human experience.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetics of the sermon are defined by a strong narrative arc that moves from the 'already' of Christ to the 'not yet' of the believer. The 'reframing' of moral struggle as a necessary part of the 'temple construction' is aesthetically and theologically potent. While the structure is occasionally cyclical, it maintains tension by refusing to offer a premature 'dedication' or victory. It is a 'sober' structure that honors the complexity of the human condition while remaining firmly anchored in the promise of grace.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon is remarkably free of religious kitsch. It explicitly rejects 'cheap comfort' and 'happy endings' in the present life. Augustine’s refusal to allow the believer a sense of 'sinlessness' or 'immediate victory' is the antithesis of kitsch. He sustains the 'pain of the blade' and the 'sighs of the combatant' without rushing to a sentimental resolution. The emotion is authentic because it is rooted in the 'wretchedness' of the human condition (Romans 7), not in manufactured sentimentality. The 'Space for Grace' is opened precisely because the 'Space for Self-Sufficiency' is brutally closed.
examples_of_kitsch: None identified; the sermon actively deconstructs the 'kitsch' of immediate moral perfection.
The potential kitsch of 'Jesus is the answer' is avoided by the complex explanation of the 'delay' of grace.
authentic_moments: The description of the 'combatant's sigh' in §7.
The honest admission that 'you never reach the point where you no longer have evil inclinations' in §6.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain this 'anti-kitsch' stance by continuing to resist the urge to provide 'easy' moral victories.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: The sermon is a profound meditation on Cilliers' 'Space for Grace.' By emphasizing that the 'widening of the heart' is something God must help us do, Augustine creates a space where human effort is situated within divine action. The 'delay' of God is framed not as absence, but as a specific kind of 'grace' that prevents pride. This sustains the tension between 'already' and 'not yet' beautifully. The mystery of the 'thorn in the flesh' is respected as a 'counter-poison,' leaving room for the 'unavailable' work of God in suffering. It is not a moralistic 'we must,' but a 'God gives' that prevails.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between the 'spirit' and the 'flesh' is sustained throughout, with no false resolution offered for the present life.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The mystery of why God allows the 'angel of Satan' to harass the faithful is respected and framed as a divine medicine.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails; even the 'walking by the Spirit' is framed as a response to the gift of the Spirit.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To create even more space, the preacher could lean further into the 'unavailability' of grace, perhaps through more 'open' questions that leave the hearer in wonder.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon represents a high point of 'Sober-Reformed' (or rather, proto-Reformed Patristic) aesthetics. Its strength lies in the seamless integration of a dominant architectural metaphor with a rigorous theological diagnosis of the human soul. Augustine avoids the 'kitsch' of easy piety by dwelling in the tension of Romans 7, creating a 'Space for Grace' that is both intellectually demanding and pastorally consoling. The poetics of the language are marked by a rhythmic, oral quality that utilizes the best of classical rhetoric to serve the Gospel. While the structure is occasionally dense and the dogmatic boundaries are firm, the sermon remains an 'open work' in its honest portrayal of the Christian life as a 'construction site' rather than a finished palace. It is a work of 'sober beauty' that directs the hearer away from the preacher and toward the 'Divine Physician.'
strengths_top_3: The consistent and evocative 'Temple' metaphor that frames the entire sermon.
The 'anti-kitsch' honesty regarding the persistence of sin and the struggle of the will.
The rhythmic, dialogical 'oral' quality of the prose that ensures high engagement.
improvement_points_top_3: Increase the 'showing' by providing more concrete, sensory examples of modern 'works of the flesh'.
Tighten the dramaturgical transitions between the different biblical 'scenes' (Temple vs. Combat).
Utilize more 'open' rhetorical questions to allow the hearer more interpretive space.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Space for Grace) and Paul Scott Wilson (Imagery/Four Pages).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Hearers who value intellectual depth, theological precision, and an honest, non-sentimental approach to the struggles of the Christian life.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with a more linear narrative 'plot' to see if it increases the sense of movement.
Incorporate more 'everyday' imagery to complement the 'high' biblical metaphors.
Practice the 'staccato' sections to ensure the rhythmic impact is maximized in delivery.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: Aesthetically, this sermon is a robust example of how 'form is content.' The 'construction' of the sermon mirrors the 'construction' of the soul it describes. It avoids the pitfalls of aestheticism by ensuring every rhetorical flourish serves the central 'reframing' of grace. It is a 'strong' sermon (7.6) that serves as a model for how to handle complex theological truths with poetic and dramaturgical care, without ever sacrificing the 'sharpness' of the Gospel for the sake of 'beauty.'
